| [Jasey DePriest (she / her) :donor:](she / her) | [12/15/2022 22:04:09](https://infosec.exchange/@jrdepriest/109519952237071129) |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 <p>While looking for a better way to get the <em>best</em> <code>lastLogon</code> time from AD, I found this TechNet Blog Post about <a href="https://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/22461.understanding-the-ad-account-attributes-lastlogon-lastlogontimestamp-and-lastlogondate.aspx" target="_blank" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer">LastLogon, LastLogonTimeStamp, and LastLogonDate</a><br>As some of you probably already know, the <code>lastLogon</code> value is not replicated. It is only updated on the specific DC that authenticates a user for any given session. <code>LastLogonTimeStamp</code> <strong>is</strong> replicated but, by default, it can be up to 14 or more days out of date.<br>So I wanted to query every single domain controller for the value then compare them and spit out the most recent one.<br>That blog post has a one-liner for getting all the <code>lastLogon</code> values:</p><pre><code>$(foreach ($DC in ((get-addomaincontroller -filter * | sort name).name) ){ $user = get-aduser chris -properties lastlogon -server $dc | select name,lastlogon ; echo "$DC - $(w32tm /ntte $user.lastlogon)" }  )<br></code></pre><p>It takes about 5 seconds to run.<br>Where <code>chris</code> is the Identity you are searching for.<br>You could easily sort it and pick the most recent.<br>Unfortunately, I need to do this for thousands of user IDs across a dozen domain controllers.<br>So I created an update using <code>-Parallel</code>. You also need to set a <code>SamAccountName</code> to search for.</p><pre><code>$DCList = (Get-ADDomainController -Filter *).Name<br>$BestLastLogon = (($DCList | ForEach-Object -Parallel {<br>    $DC = $_;<br>    (Get-AdUser -Server $DC -Identity $using:SamAccountName -Properties lastLogon).lastLogon<br>} -ThrottleLimit 24) | Sort-Object -Desc)[0]<br>$BestLastLogon<br>$(w32tm /ntte $BestLastLogon)<br></code></pre><p>This takes about 1.5 seconds to run.</p><p>The version I use is in my production script is more complicated because I needed to account for a DC timing out and then retrying, but you get the idea.</p><p>I really want to wrap this up into a function, but I keep running into errors so I thought I'd post it here.</p><p><a href="https://infosec.exchange/tags/powershell" class="mention hashtag" rel="tag">#<span>powershell</span></a> <a href="https://infosec.exchange/tags/lastlogon" class="mention hashtag" rel="tag">#<span>lastlogon</span></a> <a href="https://infosec.exchange/tags/activedirectory" class="mention hashtag" rel="tag">#<span>activedirectory</span></a></p> Learning about Objects and methods, not only how to use some of them but if you are not sure how to use them where to find how to use them. </p><p>Like let&#39;s take for example if you wanted to get the BIOS version of your PC. You would start with the cmdlet help Get-WmiObject -ShowWindow. Then you could scroll down through the window to see different examples, one of them being -Class Win32_Bios.  So then we use the cmdlet Get-WmiObject -Class Win_32_Bios | gm . The gm is the alias for Get-Member, which will list out the different properties and methods that can be run with the cmdlet. So the property we are looking for is BIOSVersion, so now we can build up the full cmdlet.  Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_Bios | Select-Object BIOSVersion , once we run this command in PowerShell we will be given our BIOS version. Put the configuration for your prompt and PSReadLine into a separate file. **Not** in your in your profile. Let&#39;s call it interactive.ps1</p><p>2. Make sure you set your prompt at the bottom of interactive.ps1, and call it.</p><p>3. At the bottom of your profile, put:<br /> <br />function prompt {<br />&amp; $PSScriptRoot/interactive.ps1<br />}</p><p>Now your readline &amp; prompt customization only run when you need them, and don&#39;t slow non-interactive use like `pwsh -c`</p>                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             |
